content.description: The east and north faces of the boulder offer up a number of possible slab climbs. All of these are pretty low angle which make them great choices for kids and newer climbers. You can also climb them without hands for an added challenge.
content.location: Located on the east and north faces. Choose your own adventure.

content.description: Start standing with hands matched on a large right-facing jug. Traverse leftwards using holds at around 8 feet or lower (the top of the boulder is 'off') to gain the higher jug used on 'Short Story' and then finish as for that problem. A fun and tricky climb that gives climbers the opportunity to get a bit more climbing in than some of the other climbs.
content.location: This is located on the south face of the boulder. It starts on the right side of the face on an obvious right-facing jug. It is the green line on the topo photo.

content.description: Start sitting/crouching with both hands matched on the obvious flat jug. Make a big move up to another juggy shelf and use it to gain the top of the boulder. Though a bit short, great rock quality and fun moves on friendly holds make this the likely best line on the boulder.
content.location: This is the rightmost line on the west face of the boulder. It is the yellow line in the topo photo.

content.description: Start standing with the left hand on a knob on the arete at around 6 feet. Climb the right side of the arete to a slopey topout. Cool movement, though a bit sharp.
content.location: This is the leftmost line of the west face of the boulder. It climbs the obvious arete. It is the blue line on the topo photo.

content.description: Start crouching/standing as for 'Due West', with hands utilizing any of the obvious left-facing rails at 5 feet. Instead of heading straight up, make a big move rightwards to gain a right-angling rail feature and follow this rightwards to an easy top out.
content.location: This is located on the west face of the boulder. It starts the same as 'Due West'. It is the red/orange line on the topo.

content.description: Start crouching or standing with hands utilizing any of the obvious left-facing rails at 5 feet. Make a long move to a good edge and continue upwards on improving holds. A bit sharp and a bit grainy, but that should clean up with more traffic.
content.location: This is located on the west face of the boulder and is the second route from the left. See the topo photo for specific location.

content.description: This small area offers up one worthwhile boulder with around 5-10 possible lines, depending on your level of creativity and/or interest in traverses and linkups. The boulder is around 10 feet tall, but offers up more climbing than the height might suggest. Most climbs are in the v0-v2 range, though it's possible to make up harder variations, eliminates and linkups.The ease of access makes this boulder a great choice for a short session. It's possible to climb all of these lines without a pad as the landings are sandy and free of rocks.
